linesensor.h

00001 // *********************************
00002 // LINE SENSOR FUNCTIONS AND DEFINES
00003 //
00004 // Usage notes: these functions
00005 // assume the following pin mappings
00006 // PB2-PB3      : Sensors 1-2
00007 // PD2-PD7      : Sensors 3-8
00008 // *********************************
00009 #ifndef LINESENSOR_H
00010 #define LINESENSOR_H
00011 
00012 #include "inc/hw_types.h"
00013 #include "inc/hw_ints.h"
00014 #include "inc/hw_memmap.h"
00015 #include "driverlib/gpio.h"
00016 #include "driverlib/pin_map.h"
00017 #include "driverlib/sysctl.h"
00018 #include "driverlib/interrupt.h"
00019 #include "driverlib/timer.h"
00020 #include "RASLib/timer.h"
00021 
00022 //*****************************************************************************
00023 //
00024 // If building with a C++ compiler, make all of the definitions in this header
00025 // have a C binding.
00026 //
00027 //*****************************************************************************
00028 #ifdef __cplusplus
00029 extern "C"
00030 {
00031 #endif
00032                   
00033 #define NUM_SENSORS (8)                                 // the number of sensors
00034 typedef unsigned char linesensor_t;             // the line sensor data type
00035 
00036 // Summary: Initializes the appropriate GPIO
00037 // Note:        Always call this function before any other sensor-related functions
00038 //                      Initializes dischargeTime to a default value of 1000 us
00039 
00040 extern void InitializeLineSensor(void);
00041 // Summary:     Same as above, but sets up the line sensor for asynchronous operation.
00042 //                      This means the line sensor will update automatically in the background
00043 // Note:        Avoid mixing both normal and asynchronous operation
00044 // Note:        Uses TIMER0. If you use asynchronous line sensing, you should not use TIMER0 elsewhere in your code;
00045 //                      If you use TIMER0 in your code, you should not use asynchronous line sensing.
00046 extern void InitializeLineSensorAsync(void);
00047 
00048 // Summary: Sets the discharge time
00049 // Parameters:
00050 //              dischargeTime: the new discharge time 
00051 //                              constraints: 120 <= dischargeTime <= 2600
00052 // Note:        This function applies to both normal and asynchronous operation
00053 extern void SetDischargeTime(unsigned long dischargeTime);
00054 
00055 // Summary:     Reads the current line sensor values
00056 // Note:        this method takes 10 us + dischargeTime to execute
00057 // Returns:     a package of bits corresponding to the current readings from the line sensor
00058 extern linesensor_t ReadLineSensor(void);
00059 
00060 // Summary:     Same as above, but immediately returns the last automatically-updated reading
00061 // Note:        Uses TIMER0. If you use asynchronous line sensing, you should not use TIMER0 elsewhere in your code;
00062 //                      If you use TIMER0 in your code, you should not use asynchronous line sensing.
00063 extern linesensor_t ReadLineSensorAsync(void);
00064 
00065 //*****************************************************************************
00066 //
00067 // Mark the end of the C bindings section for C++ compilers.
00068 //
00069 //*****************************************************************************
00070 #ifdef __cplusplus
00071 }
00072 #endif
00073 
00074 #endif // LINESENSOR_H
